author: Joshua Greene

review: After over a month of pretty regular (daily) use, I have to say that I'm very impressed with the Amazon Fire TV.  I used to stream to our old xbox 360, and this little device is tiny, fast and responsive, and I have yet to have ANY drop in resolution or quality while watching.  For reference, I stream via an 802.11ac wifi router one floor directly above the Amazon Fire device.  The menu is good and fairly intuitive, though Amazon does make it tough to tell when something is free (we have Amazon Prime) and when something needs to be purchased.  Maybe there's a way to search one or the other, but I haven't found it.  The voice command works well, but only searches downloaded and/or Amazon products, it doesn't link you to Netflix or other services, so your search for "Sci-Fi Horror" will be limited, for example.  All in all though, a solid, elegant and reliable streaming option.  I like being able to stream music I've purchased on Amazon straight to my TV set, and I hope that Amazon Prime music gets added soon.

review: Overall this device is pretty slick.  There are a few things that would push it to 5 stars.Amazon needs to add a speed test AP for the fire tv.  I have rarely seen issues with stream buffering and I think it was on my side, but it would be nice if I could run a speed test to verify my download speeds with my router.  Amazon has an AP for the fire tablet.  They just need to add one for the fire tv.I also wish the usb port on the back would recognize a flash drive.  It would be nice to have extra storage capability since it only comes with 8 gig.  Some of the games available are quite big.

author: Colin Paddock

review: I use my FireTV daily. It's not perfect, but no set top box is. I find the FireTV to be far superior to the Roku 2 and older. I've not tried a Roku 3, but I'd prefer an Amazon box anyway. I really like the added gaming options and the speed of the box. I also think Amazon has only begun to add content and develop their platform. I find that I can use my FireTV and my Chromcast to do anything I need. I actually gave away my Roku after I started using my FireTV. I do still keep a Roku 2 for the bedroom, but mainly for the headphone jack on the remote.Overall, in comparison to the other set top boxes I've used Amazon is by far the winner in my book. Purely for it's speed and integration into the Amazon ecosystem. I trust Amazon's track record and they tend to give customers what they want. I see a bright future for the FireTV.
